This article has been retracted [1] by the authors because errors were noted in the methodology employed in the experiments which invalidate the results reported. The authors apologise for any inconvenience caused.

column19:
unless otherwise stated.issue-copyright-statement© The Author(s) 2015Retraction

The Publisher and Editor regretfully retract this article [1] because the peer-review process was inappropriately influenced and compromised. As a result
column20: the scientific integrity of the article cannot be guaranteed. A systematic and detailed investigation suggests that a third party was involved in supplying fabricated details of potential peer reviewers for a large number of manuscripts submitted to different journals. In accordance with recommendations from [<ext-link ext-link-type=""uri"" xlink:href=""http://publicationethics.org/news/cope-statement-inappropriate-manipulation-peer-review-processes#_blank"">COPE</ext-link>] we have retracted all affected published articles
column21:
including this one. It was not possible to determine beyond doubt that the authors of this particular article were aware of any third party attempts to manipulate peer review of their manuscript.

The online version of the original article can be found under doi:10.1186/ar4308

column6:
the article titled “A Rare Pathological Entity of Multiple Calcified Hyperplastic Dental Follicles” [1] has been retracted. The contents of the article are no longer available online in order to protect the patient's confidentiality.

The article titled “Intravenous Leiomyoma with Extension to the Heart: A Case Report and Review of the Literature” [1]
column6: published in Case Reports in Obstetrics and Gynecology
column7: has been retracted as it is found to contain a substantial amount of material
column9: from the published article titled “Surgical management of intravenous leiomyoma with cardiac extension. Do we need total circulatory arrest?” by S. Senay
column14: The Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgeon 2007; 55(5): 322-323. DOI: 10.1055/s-2007-964953. Also
column15:
the article was submitted for publication by Veysel Sal without the knowledge and approval of the coauthors Umit Kaya and Cem Alhan.

Case Reports in Psychiatry has retracted the article titled “Combined Case of Blood-Injury-Injection Phobia and Social Phobia: Behavior Therapy Management and Effectiveness through Tilt Test” [1]. The article was found to contain a substantial amount of material from published articles
column7:
including the following:

Heimberg RG et al.: Psychometric properties of the Liebowitz Social Anxiety Scale. Psychological Medicine
column12:
Ritz T: Treatments for blood-injury-injection phobia: a critical review of current evidence. J Psychiatr Res. 2009 Oct; 43(15):1235-42. doi: 10.1016/j.jpsychires.2009.04.008;

Lars-Göran Öst
column13: Ulf Sterner: A specific behavioral method for treatment of blood phobia. Behaviour Research and Therapy Volume 25
column18: Jan Johansson: Individual response patterns and the effects of different behavioral methods in the treatment of social phobia. Behaviour Research and Therapy. Volume 19
column21:
Pages 1–16 doi: 10.1016/0005-7967(81)90107-8;

Ryan C. Shorey and Gregory L. Stuart: Manualized Cognitive-Behavioral Treatment of Social Anxiety Disorder: A Case Study. Clin Case Stud. 2012 Feb 1; 11(1): 35–47. doi: 10.1177/1534650112438462 (not cited).

At the request of the authors
column6: the article titled “A Fatal Case of Wernicke's Encephalopathy after Sleeve Gastrectomy for Morbid Obesity” [<xref rid=""B1"" ref-type=""bibr"">1</xref>] has been retracted. The coroner reviewed the case and postmortem histopathology and concluded that the typical histopathological lesions of Wernicke's encephalopathy were absent
column7: therefore not confirming the initial diagnosis. Reexamination of the patient's file showed that postoperative vitamin B1 levels were within the institutional reference range; no hyperemesis and no neurological signs were revealed. The article stated that “This report is published with the written consent of the patient's family
column8:
” but there was misunderstanding and the family did not give explicit permission for publication.

ManatakisD. K.GeorgopoulosN.A fatal case of Wernicke’s encephalopathy after sleeve gastrectomy for morbid obesityCase Reports in Surgery20142014428121010.1155/2014/281210" """article-type=.retraction"""

column2: exposure to dampness and the severity of asthma</article-title></title-group><contrib-group><contrib contrib-type=""author"" corresp=""yes"" id=""A1""><name><surname>Hemilä</surname><given-names>Harri</given-names></name><xref ref-type=""aff"" rid=""I1"">1</xref><email>harri.hemila@helsinki.fi</email></contrib><contrib contrib-type=""author"" id=""A2""><name><surname>Al-Biltagi</surname><given-names>Mohammed</given-names></name><xref ref-type=""aff"" rid=""I2"">2</xref><email>mbelrem@hotmail.com</email></contrib><contrib contrib-type=""author"" id=""A3""><name><surname>Baset</surname><given-names>Ahmed Abdul</given-names></name><xref ref-type=""aff"" rid=""I2"">2</xref><email>eltayar2000@yahoo.com</email></contrib></contrib-group><aff id=""I1""><label>1</label>Department of Public Health
column10: Egypt</aff><pub-date pub-type=""collection""><year>2012</year></pub-date><pub-date pub-type=""epub""><day>16</day><month>3</month><year>2012</year></pub-date><volume>2</volume><fpage>6</fpage><lpage>6</lpage><history><date date-type=""received""><day>12</day><month>3</month><year>2012</year></date><date date-type=""accepted""><day>16</day><month>3</month><year>2012</year></date></history><permissions><copyright-statement>Copyright ©2012 Hemilä et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.</copyright-statement><copyright-year>2012</copyright-year><copyright-holder>Hemilä et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.</copyright-holder><license license-type=""open-access"" xlink:href=""http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0""><license-p>This is an Open Access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution License (<ext-link ext-link-type=""uri"" xlink:href=""http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0"">http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0</ext-link>)
column14: provided the original work is properly cited.<p>We reported that the effect of vitamin C on asthma in Egyptian children was modified by age
column15: exposure to dampness and the severity of asthma [<xref ref-type=""bibr"" rid=""B1"">1</xref>]. After our paper was published
column16: we found out severe problems in the data set. There were 60 children in the study. The ages were by accident duplicated between the upper and lower halves of the database. Thus
column17: the ages for the first 30 children in the data set were identical and in the same order with the ages for the second set of 30 children. Similar duplication was also found for C-ACT and FEV1 measurements after vitamin C supplementation and for exposure to dampness. This duplication thus directly invalidates the second part of the data set
column18: and thus the reported outcome. We have not been able to sort out the reason for this duplication. The files with the original data are not available any more
column19:
making it impossible to reconstruct a valid data set for reanalysis. Therefore we have to retract our paper. The authors deeply regret the inconvenience this has caused to the journal and the scientific community.

HemiläHAl-BiltagiMBassetAAVitamin C and asthma in children: modification of the effect by age

column4:
provided the original work is properly cited.294-304

CLINICS 2017;72(5):294-304

Retraction requested by the Editor of CLINICS in agreement with the authors

Retraction type: Redundant publication

Comments: The same article was published almost simultaneously in the journal TRANSLATIONAL NEUROSCIENCE AND CLINICS with a different title: “Factors affecting the prognosis of children with medulloblastoma: A single institution retrospective analysis of 40 cases” (http://www.tncjournal.com/EN/10.18679/CN11-6030/R.2017.003).

All articles submitted to CLINICS undergo strict quality control and are checked using iThenticate software before being submitted for peer review and before acceptance. The retracted article was checked on September 26
column8: the article was published in TRANSLATIONAL NEUROSCIENCE AND CLINICS in May 2017
column9:
so there was no way of acknowledging the publication during the evaluation process. The authors submitted all required copyright transfer documents stating that the manuscript had not been submitted to any other journal.

The authors stated the following: “It was an unintentional mistake caused by carelessness. After acceptance of our article in CLINICS
column10: we attended a seminar. TRANSLATIONAL NEUROSCIENCE AND CLINICS indexed our paper after the seminar
column11: and we knew nothing about this at that time. We misunderstood and thought that this would not influence the publication of our paper in CLINICS as TRANSLATIONAL NEUROSCIENCE AND CLINICS is a non-SCI journal
column12:
and the paper was indexed only internally.”

column20:
provided the original work is properly cited.Aim

To determine the reasons for large standard deviation of bronchodilator response (BDR) and establish whether there is a potential heritable component in healthy subjects.

Methods

67 monozygotic and 42 dizygotic adult twin pairs were assessed for bronchodilator response (%change in FEV1 after inhaling 400 µg salbutamol). Univariate quantitative genetic modeling was performed.

Results

Multiple regression modeling showed a significant association between BDR and sex and baseline FEV1 (P < 0.05)
column21: while no association was found with smoking habits
column23: or age. Within pair correlation in monozygotic twins was modest (0.332)
column24: but higher than in dizygotic twins (0.258). Age-
column26: and baseline FEV1-adjusted genetic effect accounted for 14.9% (95% confidence interval
column27: CI 0%-53.1%) of the variance of BDR
column29:
and unshared environmental effect for 66.8% (95% CI 46.8%-88.7%).

Conclusion

Our twin study showed that individual differences in BDR can be mostly explained by unshared environmental effects. In addition
column30: it is the first study to show low
column34:
and baseline FEV1.

The assessment of the reversibility of airway obstruction is a key element in the diagnosis of airway diseases and can also be a sign of the potential therapeutic effect of a specific inhaled drug (1
column35: <xref rid=""R2"" ref-type=""bibr"">2</xref>). Bronchodilator response (BDR) is tested after the inhalation of a drug and is defined as the change in spirometric parameters including forced vital capacity (FVC)
column37: and mid-expiratory flow 25%-75%. Although no consensus exists
column38: the latest American Thoracic Society (ATS)/European Respiratory Society (ERS) guideline recommends that
column40:
an increase in FEV1 or FVC>12% and ≥200 mL from baseline is considered a significant BDR (3).

Large population studies proposed a different threshold of BDR that has a role in clinical interpretation of airway response to a bronchodilator (4
column42: underlying reasons for the large variation of BDR and a potential heritable component in healthy population are still unclear. It is known that certain genetic polymorphisms are associated with BDR in asthmatic (<xref rid=""R6"" ref-type=""bibr"">6</xref>
column43: <xref rid=""R7"" ref-type=""bibr"">7</xref>) and non-asthmatic (<xref rid=""R8"" ref-type=""bibr"">8</xref>
column44: <xref rid=""R9"" ref-type=""bibr"">9</xref>) individuals. This is supported by the fact that there are differences in BDR among different nations (<xref rid=""R10"" ref-type=""bibr"">10</xref>). These studies strongly support a hereditary influence on BDR
column45: but they cannot fully describe the relationship of hereditary and environmental factors on the development of BDR. Assessing familial aggregation of BDR
column46:
Niu et al found a modest familial clustering (11).

Family design can determine inter-generation resemblance or difference
column48: in contrast to the twin study design
column49: it does not determine the influence of outside factors such as family
column52: family studies cannot reliably distinguish the influence of heritability from common environmental effects. Numerous twin studies examined airway hyperresponsiveness (AHR) (<xref rid=""R13"" ref-type=""bibr"">13</xref>-<xref rid=""R18"" ref-type=""bibr"">18</xref>)
column53: but none of them investigated BDR. Although BDR is usually associated with AHR in obstructive airway diseases (<xref rid=""R19"" ref-type=""bibr"">19</xref>)
column54: previous twin results on AHR cannot simply be extended to BDR. Therefore
column55:
the first aim of this study is to determine which factors affect BDR in a healthy twin population. As a second aim we investigated whether the large standard deviation of BDR in healthy asymptomatic subjects could be attributable to genetic or environmental factors.

Participants and methodsParticipants

One hundred and nine adult twin pairs (67 monozygotic [MZ] and 42 dizygotic [DZ]) were recruited from the Hungarian Twin Registry (20) as part of the International Twin Study 2009. Zygosity was assessed using a standard validated questionnaire concerning the degree of physical similarity of twins during infancy. Zygosity determination through this method is >99% accurate (21). The study protocols were approved by the institutional review board for human studies of Semmelweis University
column57: Hungary (Regional and Institutional Committee of Science and Research Ethics
column58:
29/2009) and written consent was obtained from each participant or their surrogate.

Study design

Participants were recruited from general population via email
column61: or during twin festivals. Exclusion criteria included pregnancy
column62: acute respiratory infection within three weeks of measurement
column63: chronic obstructive airway diseases including asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
column64: or foreseeable lack of compliance with test procedures. Participants were tested in two large hospitals in Budapest
column65: Hungary by the same trained personnel (DLT
column67: they were asked to refrain from smoking for at least 3 hours
column68: drinking alcohol or coffee for 10 hours
column69:
and eating for 1 hour.

Baseline lung function measurement

Lung function was assessed by dynamic spirometry (Minispir
column72:
USA). The spirometer was calibrated daily using a 1-L syringe. FEV1 measurements were performed in accordance with guidelines of the American Thoracic Society/European Respiratory Society Task Force (22).

Bronchodilator response

Following the baseline lung function assessment
column73:
all participants inhaled 400 µg salbutamol in line with the ATS/ERS guidelines (22). BDR was assessed by bronchodilator response (change in FEV1 after inhaling 400 µg salbutamol). Salbutamol was inhaled from a metered dose inhaler without a spacer device and post- bronchodilator spirometry was recorded after 15 minutes. Bronchial reversibility was considered if the increase in FEV1 was at least 12% and 200 mL (23). No side effects were observed following the BDR tests.

Statistical analysis

Descriptive statistics (mean ± standard deviation for continuous variables
column74: percentage for categorical variables) were computed for MZ and DZ twins separately. MZ and DZ subsamples were compared by <italic>t</italic> test for paired samples. Multiple regression analysis identified potential variables associated with BDR
column75:
which were included as covariates in subsequent twin structural equation models. Regression analysis used robust estimation of standard errors to adjust for the clustering of data between twin and co-twin within pair.

Twin resemblance within MZ and DZ pairs was evaluated using Pearson correlation coefficients obtained with a saturated model in the Mx software (24); the saturated model was specified by constraining means and variances to be the same for twin and co-twin
column76: and for MZ and DZ twins. A higher correlation in MZ than in DZ pairs suggests a contribution of genetic factors to the phenotype
column77: similar correlation in MZ and DZ pairs suggests a contribution of shared environmental factors
column78: while low correlation in MZ pairs compared to DZ twins suggests a contribution of unshared environmental factors. In particular
column79: the genetic component is approximated by twice the difference between MZ and DZ correlation (2(MZ-DZ)) and the unshared environmental component is approximated by 1-MZ correlation (<xref rid=""R24"" ref-type=""bibr"">24</xref>
column80:
25).

Biometric univariate structural equation models were fitted to estimate the relative importance of hereditary and environmental effects on percent variation in FEV1 values (using the % change in FEV1 as a continuous variable) (24
column81: <xref rid=""R26"" ref-type=""bibr"">26</xref>). These models incorporate latent variables for genetic and environmental influence and observed variables for measured FEV<sub>1</sub> change in twins. The effect of latent variables on observed variables is inferred from the observed variances and covariances by exploiting the fact that MZ twins share 100% of their genes
column82:
while DZ twins share 50% of the genetic background. Twin models assume that relevant environmental exposures are shared by the twins to the same extent regardless of zygosity (“equal environments assumption”) (24).

Using these models
column83: it is possible to decompose the phenotypic variance of BDR into additive genetic (A)
column85: and unshared environmental (E) components (ACE model). Shared environment includes those factors that are not related to individual lifestyle
column89: while unique environment includes smoking or nutrition. All twin analyses were adjusted by age
column91: and baseline FEV1. The analyses were carried out with Stata (version 11.0
column95: USA) and Mx softwares (Department of Psychiatry Virginia Institute for Psychiatric and Behavioral Genetics
column98:
USA) (27). The level of statistical significance was set at P < 0.05.

Results

61.5% of twins were MZ and 38.5% were DZ (72% women) (Table 1). No significant difference between the groups was observed in age
column100: and smoking prevalence. DZ twins had higher FEV<sub>1</sub> change compared to MZ twins
column101: although the difference was not significant (3.4 ± 6.5 vs 2.0 ± 5.5%
column102: <italic>P</italic> = 0.278). 11 participants had a positive BDR test. Although BDR (FEV<sub>1</sub> change) showed no correlation with baseline FVC (L) (<italic>P</italic> > 0.05)

Intraclass correlation of percent change in FEV1 was modest but higher in MZ twins (rMZ = 0.332
column132: suggesting a weak genetic effect in the expression of BDR. ACE analysis indicated that genetic and shared environmental effects were modest and that they together explained about one-third of total variance in FEV<sub>1</sub> change (A:15%

Discussion

Although the assessment of bronchodilator response has become routine in clinical practice
column144: background of the large variation of BDR in asymptomatic persons has remained unclear. BDR response is a common
column145: but not a specific measure of bronchial asthma
column146: which has considerable prevalence among non-asthmatic persons (<xref rid=""R28"" ref-type=""bibr"">28</xref>). We found that BDR was weakly influenced by genetic factors and shared environment
column147: and strongly influenced by unshared environmental factors. This result might clarify the large standard deviation of BDR responses in asymptomatic persons without airways disease. The finding that unshared environmental component mainly explains the variation also suggests the importance of prevention (eg
column148: smoking prevention in persons with high-risk for asthma/COPD or lifestyle modification). Accordingly
column149: our results highlight that lifestyle factors have an important role in the determination of BDR test results in individuals without lung diseases
column150:
so these factors should be eliminated before BDR assessment and be taken into account in the interpretation of the results.

Genetic influences have been investigated in diseases related to pathologic BDR. For example
column151: heritability of asthma has been widely demonstrated (<xref rid=""R29"" ref-type=""bibr"">29</xref>-<xref rid=""R34"" ref-type=""bibr"">34</xref>). Although the current twin study is the first study investigating BDR
column153: another common characteristic of asthma (<xref rid=""R13"" ref-type=""bibr"">13</xref>-<xref rid=""R18"" ref-type=""bibr"">18</xref>). Hopp et al suggested the role of hereditary influences on airway hyperresponsiveness to methacholine by simply estimating the MZ and DZ correlations for twin pairs (6-31 years) (<xref rid=""R15"" ref-type=""bibr"">15</xref>). They also reported that increased non-specific bronchial reactivity was persistent and associated with allergy (<xref rid=""R14"" ref-type=""bibr"">14</xref>). Zamel et al demonstrated in ten MZ and ten DZ healthy
column154: nonsmoking twins the major role of environmental factors in determining the variability of acute AHR to bronchoactive drugs (<xref rid=""R18"" ref-type=""bibr"">18</xref>). An Australian twin study in 381 twin pairs aged 8 to 18 years suggested that hereditary effects may be largely shared between asthma
column156: and AHR (<xref rid=""R13"" ref-type=""bibr"">13</xref>). Lund et al reported no heritability for AHR in younger adult twins (age 18-31 years) (<xref rid=""R16"" ref-type=""bibr"">16</xref>) and that shared environmental factors explained 30% of the AHR variance (<xref rid=""R16"" ref-type=""bibr"">16</xref>). These factors may include diet
column157: exposure to high levels of air pollution
column158: parental smoking and other conditions in the parental home
column162: we found a weak hereditary component for BDR (15%) and a similar (67%) unshared environmental component. Unshared environmental factors may include differences in diseases and occupational exposures. This is supported by a previous study reporting a relationship between bronchial hyperresponsiveness and infections after the neonatal period in school-aged twins (<xref rid=""R35"" ref-type=""bibr"">35</xref>). Apart from twin studies
column163: there is evidence from familial aggregation studies
column166: and genome-wide linkage analyses of hereditary influence on BDR
column167: suggesting that interactions between genes and environmental components may also be involved (<xref rid=""R13"" ref-type=""bibr"">13</xref>
column169:
36-40).

Smoking status is an important environmental factor to be examined. Although smoking increases the risk of airway responsiveness (36)
column170: Lund et al in their heritability analysis did not analyze the effect of smoking (<xref rid=""R16"" ref-type=""bibr"">16</xref>). In the present study
column171: the twin sample comprised 32.9% active or ex-smokers. Although the association of smoking with AHR is well known (<xref rid=""R41"" ref-type=""bibr"">41</xref>)
column172: we did not observe a significant role of smoking status on BDR; however
column173: this may be explained by the relatively low rate of active smokers (17.3%). Accordingly
column174: the effect of smoking on the ACE models was not assessed. The lack of relationship between smoking status and BDR is not surprising
column175: as a study conducted in a large cohort of patients with obstructive airway disease showed that BDR was related to smoking history rather than to current smoking status (<xref rid=""R19"" ref-type=""bibr"">19</xref>). However
column176:
we could not completely eliminate the possible effects of smoking on ACE modeling by stratifying the quantitative genetic analyses according to pair-wise smoking status and analyzing the non-smokers only. This limitation should be considered in future larger twin studies investigating the effect of smoking on the heritability of BDR. Structural equation modeling has decreased power to assess models (for genetic vs shared environmental vs unique environmental components) when the genetic effect is low (less than ~ 20%) (42). This also prevented the exploration of sex differences in the heritability and environmental effects on BDR.

The main strength of the present study is that all BDR tests were performed by the same trained researchers and the same validated device at all sites. Furthermore
column177: the results can be generalized to the non-twin adult population
column178:
assuming that the enrolled twins did not differ from non-twin individuals with regard to the considered traits.

In conclusion
column179: the present study revealed a low heritability of BDR independently of sex
column181: and baseline FEV<sub>1</sub> in a healthy twin population. Unshared environmental effects explained most of the BDR variance
column182: underscoring the importance of environmental factors (eg
column184: allergens) in determining individual differences in BDR in healthy adult individuals. This finding might explain the frequently experienced large standard deviation of BDR assessments in asymptomatic persons without airways disease
column185:
emphasizing the importance of lifestyle factors that influence BDR test results.

column27:
provided the original work is properly cited.

Among the gynaecological malignancies
column28: ovarian cancer is one of the neoplastic forms with the poorest prognosis and with the bad overall and disease-free survival rates than other gynaecological cancers. Ovarian tumors can be classified on the basis of the cells of origin in epithelial
column29: stromal and germ cell tumors. Epithelial ovarian tumors display great histological heterogeneity and can be further subdivided into benign
column31: and invasive tumors. Several studies on ovarian tumors
column32: have focused on the identification of both diagnostic and prognostic markers for applications in clinical practice. High-throughput technologies have accelerated the process of biomolecular study and genomic discovery; unfortunately
column33: validity of these should be still demonstrated by extensive researches on sensibility and sensitivity of ovarian cancer novel biomarkers
column34: determining whether gene profiling and proteomics could help differentiate between patients with metastatic ovarian cancer and primary ovarian carcinomas
column35: and their potential impact on management. Therefore
column36: considerable interest lies in identifying molecular and protein biomarkers and indicators to guide treatment decisions and clinical follow up. In this review
column37: the current state of knowledge about the genoproteomic and potential clinical value of gene expression profiling in ovarian cancer and ovarian borderline tumors is discussed
column38: focusing on three main areas: distinguishing normal ovarian tissue from ovarian cancers and borderline tumors
column39: identifying different genotypes of ovarian tissue and identifying proteins linked to cancer or tumor development. By these targets
column40: authors focus on the use of novel molecules
column41: developed on the proteomics and genomics researches
column42: as potential protein biomarkers in the management of ovarian cancer or borderline tumor
column43:
overlooking on current state of the art and on future perspectives of researches.

Key WordsOvarian cancerborderline ovarian tumorsmarkersgenomicsproteomicsoncogenes.INTRODUCTION

Ovarian cancer is the sixth most frequent female cancer worldwide
column46: and the most lethal of all gynaecological cancers. Given that ovarian cancer in 75% of cases is diagnosed in advanced stage
column47: the disease has a fairly poor prognosis with an overall five-year survival of around 40%
column48:
ranging from 10% for patients with tumors with distant metastases to 80% for patients with localized tumors [1].

Ovarian tumors can be classified on the basis of the cells of origin in epithelial
column49: stromal and germ cell tumors. Epithelial ovarian neoplasms display great histological heterogeneity and can be further subdivided into benign
column50: intermediate or borderline and invasive tumors. Borderline ovarian tumors (BOTs) account for 10%-20% of ovarian epithelial tumors and are typically diagnosed before 40 years of age
column51:
raising issues regarding the use of conservative surgery to preserve fertility [2].

So
column52: despite enormous progress in cancer research
column53: this disease represents one of the principal causes of death worldwide; therefore
column54: there is a need for the identification of molecules which can act as indicators of an early malignant process
column55: when disease burden is localized. However
column56: the possibility to use many of these molecules in the clinical practice remains
column58:
still elusive.

Evaluation and validation of biomarkers need rigorous procedures to ensure clinical validity.

The process follows different steps to assist researchers in developing biomarker
column59: these phases include: preclinical exploratory studies
column62:
prospective screening and cancer control [3].

In addition
column63: genomic and proteomics technologies have increased the number of potential biomarker entering clinical development
column64: hence the validation of these candidate biomarkers require an integrated effort among government
column65:
academic and pharmaceutical groups to coordinate the activity of many laboratories [4].

GENERALITY ON PROTEOGENOMICS IN OVARIAN CANCERS

In the case of ovarian cancer specific subtypes
column66: it is often reported the evidence that different histological subtypes of ovarian cancer can be distinguished by some microarray profiling
column67:
and that these subtypes might be partly reflected by a different aetiology through the deregulation and activation of different pathways.

This neoplasm heterogeneity could also account for different ovarian tumor behaviours and it could be revealed by specific biomarkers; for this evidence
column68: it is reported by authors that gene expression profiling could be a useful prognostic tool
column69: predicting chemo sensitivity to the standard treatment combination of paclitaxel and platinum chemotherapy for advanced ovarian cancer
column70:
but more knowledge about chemo sensitivity could eventually lead to a more tailored cancer therapy [3-5].

The purpose of this study is to summarize current dates regarding the use of novel protein biomarkers
column73: prognosis and response to therapy in ovarian cancer and in borderline ovarian tumors. Our attention will be focus not only on serum markers but also on intracellular proteins. Indeed
column74: the expression of these proteins can reflect cellular and molecular mechanisms that control onset and neoplastic progression. Proteins included in this group belong to different cellular pathways including cellular metabolism and signal transduction. Of particular interest
column75:
it is the role of signaling molecules that regulate interaction pathways between tumor cells and the microenvironment.

OVARIAN TUMORS AND BORDERLINE OVARIAN TUMORS (BOTS): MARKERS ACTUALLY USED IN CLINIC PRACTICE

Widely asymptomatic at the moment of the diagnosis
column76: more than 70% of the patients with ovarian cancer are already in an advanced disease state [<xref rid=""R5"" ref-type=""bibr"">5</xref>]. On the contrary
column77: BOTs are more common in women of younger age
column78:
do not share a similar epidemiological risk profile than women with invasive disease and appear to have a distinct genetic and protein background respect to high grade tumors.

The serum CA125 in combination with transvaginal or transabdominal ultrasonography (US) have been helpful for clinicians in the diagnosis and monitoring of a suspicious ovarian formation
column79: leading to their acceptance for clinical screening [<xref rid=""R6"" ref-type=""bibr"">6</xref>]
column80:
since US is a non-invasive acceptable procedure with a large diffusion in world women screening programs and without complications.

The CA125
column82: is the only serum molecules significantly associated with ovarian cancer
column84: pelvic inflammatory disease and other conditions. Normally
column85: serum levels are less than 35 U/ml and are increased in about 90% of patients with advanced ovarian cancer (stage III-IV) but only in 50% of women with early stage disease. This protein belongs to the protein family of mucins
column86: a high molecular weight protein that normally coats the epithelium [<xref rid=""R7"" ref-type=""bibr"">7</xref>
column87: <xref rid=""R8"" ref-type=""bibr"">8</xref>]. In virtue of their localization
column88: mucine proteins have extremely important functions in cellular physiology
column91: cellular adhesion. Alterations in their oligosaccharide structure have been noticed in different cancer forms [<xref rid=""R9"" ref-type=""bibr"">9</xref>]. CA 125 is a useful marker for the assessment of response to chemotherapy
column92: predicting relapses and for discrimination between benign and malignant masses [<xref rid=""R10"" ref-type=""bibr"">10</xref>
column93: <xref rid=""R11"" ref-type=""bibr"">11</xref>]. The development of an algorithm that calculates risk of ovarian cancer
column95: has shown that 20% of ovarian cancers have little or no expression of CA125 and has pointed out the importance of additional serum markers identification
column96: as well as of new molecules capable of completing or replacing CA125 altogether
column97:
to facilitate earlier detection of ovarian cancer [12].

US in combination with CA125 has also been suggested as a potential means for early detection of ovarian cancer [13]; others studies confirmed the efficacy of this combination for the screening of ovarian cancer
column98: but a recent study from the American National Cancer Institute (NCI)
column99: shows that these two screening methods
column101: can also produce many false-positive test results
column102:
causing needless surgery [14].

For this reason
column103: evaluation of a cystic formation with US characteristic of benignity
column104: should lead to a normal echographic follow-up [<xref rid=""R13"" ref-type=""bibr"">13</xref>-<xref rid=""R15"" ref-type=""bibr"">15</xref>]. However
column105: additional studies performed with US screening have not demonstrated adequate sensitivity and sensibility for an early diagnosis of ovarian cancer [<xref rid=""R16"" ref-type=""bibr"">16</xref>]. Hereby
column107: good results were obtained by the combination of CA125 with others serum markers; serum total inhibin levels are sensitive and specific markers of epithelial ovarian cancer in postmenopausal women; the production of inhibin by the ovaries almost stops after the menopause
column108: but it continues from ovarian tumors. After menopause
column109: circular inhibin levels are undetectable; on the other hand
column110: they are elevated in women with ovarian cancer [<xref rid=""R17"" ref-type=""bibr"">17</xref>]. Inhibin is a glycoprotein that exists as a dimeric form of two subunits (α e βA o βB)
column111: to form inhibin A and inhibin B (αβA) e B (αβB); moreover
column112:
inhibin seems to be complementary to CA125 and both markers have a total 95% of sensitivity with 95% of specificity.

Studies are directed toward establishing whether there are cancer specific inhibin forms
column113: which may be suitable during the reproductive years
column114:
when these proteins show substantial fluctuations that would seriously compromise a preoperative assessment of any ovarian cancer [18].

PROTEIN MARKERS IN OVARIAN CANCER

Mesothelin is a cell surface protein present on normal mesothelial cells lining the body cavities and it is highly expressed in several cancers
column115:
including ovarian cancers.

Using mice lacking the Mesothelin gene
column116:
researchers have developed a monoclonal antibody directed against the protein and an ELISA assay for detecting serum mesothelin levels.

Elevated proteins levels have been detected in patients with mesothelioma and ovarian cancer [19]. Moreover
column117:
protein levels increase from the earlier form to more advanced cancer forms [20].

Serum mesothelin may be a useful test to monitor treatment response in mesothelin-expressing cancers
column118: because after surgery there is a rapid decrease in mesothelin levels in patients with peritoneal mesothelioma. Future studies correlating serum mesothelin with detailed clinical information
column122:
will also have to be done to determine if serum mesothelin has prognostic significance and also if it can be used as a biomarker to assess response to other therapies besides surgery [19].

Important results have been obtained even in prognosis and in monitoring response to therapy. Signal Transducer and Activator of Transcription 3 (STAT3) is a latent transcription factor in several neoplastic diseases; it normally resides in the cytoplasm and can be activated thought phosphorylation by several cytokines
column123: hormones and growth factor that play their roles using STAT3 activated pathway
column129:
and survival [21].

Expression of phosphorylated STAT3 form is increased in primary ovarian cancer and its nuclear localization is associated with a poor prognosis; further studies are needed to elucidate the mechanism of activation of Stat3
column131:
and its role in the neoplastic transformation of epithelial ovarian cells [22].

LPAAT-β (of which we know six human isoforms) is an enzyme that catalyzes the acetylation of Lisophospahtitic Acid (LPA)
column133:
acting as a second messenger in tumor cell regulation of both proliferative and survival pathways [23].

An increase of enzyme expression has been correlated to a poor prognosis and is associated with a minor survival [24]; in SK-OV-3 and IGROV1 cell lines
column134:
small interfering RNA (siRNA) was used to silence the expression of LPAAT-β reducing ovarian cancer cell lines viability [25].

LPAAT-β is an intriguing prognostic tool for the identification of high-risk epithelial ovarian cancer (EOC) and it should be a molecular target toward which to direct therapy
column135: because of the adverse clinical outcome associated with LPAAT-b expression
column136:
even for early-stage ovarian tumors [26].

Among prognostic factors in ovarian cancers there are many members of Human Kallikrein Family (hK)
column137: a serine-protease protein. This family gene is organized in a big cluster
column138: located in 19q13.4 chromosome; different immunohistochemistry studies have shown that hK8 could be considered a marker of positive prognosis in patients with ovarian cancer [<xref rid=""R27"" ref-type=""bibr"">27</xref>
column140: extensive correlative clinical data have linked the over expression of 11 other kallikreins to ovarian cancer patient prognosis [<xref rid=""R29"" ref-type=""bibr"">29</xref>]. Although most reports link high kallikrein expression with poor patient prognosis (e.g.
column147: several studies also recognize some kallikreins as favourable prognostic indicators (e.g.
column151:
and 14) [30].

These clinical findings seem to be contradictory but have been explained by authors considering that hKs and proteases in general
column152:
have a dual role during tumor progression.

Pyruvate Kinase (PK) is a key enzyme in glycolysis; the isoenzyme M2-PK is shifted to a dimeric form in a variety of tumors. Since the dimeric form is over-expressed in tumor cells
column153:
it is called pyruvate kinase tumor M2 (Tu M2-PK) [31].

Tu M2-PK is present in body fluids also
column154:
most likely released from tumor cells by tumor necrosis and cell turnover. It has been previously shown for various tumors that Tu M2-PK determination in the circulation provides excellent discrimination between benign and malignant disease or may provide additional information regarding sensitivity to chemotherapy [32-34].

In a recent study of Ahmed and colleagues
column155: it has been supposed a possible link between TuM2-PK plasmatic levels and malignancy of ovarian cancer
column156: showing that its concentration was significantly raised in ovarian cancer patients
column157: particularly those with higher stage disease [<xref rid=""R35"" ref-type=""bibr"">35</xref>]. In another study
column158:
the same researchers have tried to determine the cut-off values for TuM2-PK sensitivity and specificity for differentiating between benign and malignant ovarian disease. The average M2-PK concentration in cancer patients was 52 U/ml versus 27 U/ml in patients with benign conditions (p < 0.001). At a cut-off value of 22 U/ml the sensitivity of M2-PK for detecting cancer was 70% with a specificity of 65%. However the M2-PK role in clinical practice needs further evaluation [36].

c-MET (Mesenchymal epithelial transition factor) is a proto-oncogene that encodes for a tyrosine kinase membrane receptor [37].

The c-Met protein is expressed mostly in in mammalian tissues and plays an important role in different cellular process; its ligand is the HGF (Hepatocyte Growth Factor)
column159: known also as <italic>Scatter Factor</italic> (SF) and c-MET over-expression or inactivation is implicated in different tumoral disease [<xref rid=""R38"" ref-type=""bibr"">38</xref>]. Recently
column160: Sawada and colleagues have analyzed c-MET role in ovarian cancer biology and its possible implication as a therapeutic target; so
column161: it has been established the c-MET over-expression
column162:
especially in patients in higher stage disease [38].

That c-MET level could represent a potential prognostic marker for patient with higher stage EOC has already been shown by the studies of Ayhan et al. [39].

But in Sawada et al. study
column163: silencing of c-MET messenger in SKOV-3ip1 cells
column164: cause inhibition of cellular adhesion to different extra cellular matrix components and human primary mesothelial cells; in parallel a significative reduction of α-integrin and β-integrin
column165:
urokinase and matrix metalloproteinase (MMP)-2/MMP-9 activity has been observed.

In summary
column166: this study shows that c-Met is highly expressed in a subset of ovarian cancer patients and that its inhibition can reduce adhesion
column169: and ultimately tumor burden. It is tempting to speculate that
column170: after the optimal surgical debulking of a patient with ovarian cancer
column171:
consolidation therapy with a drug that targets metastasis will delay the repopulation of the peritoneal cavity by ovarian cancer cells [38].

Moreover
column172: in 2003 Maggiora <italic>et al</italic>. have established a link between c-MET and RON
column173: another member of Tyrosin-kinase receptor gene family
column174:
whose mutation is related to tumorigenesis.

It has been demonstrated that
column178: and cooperate in inducing morphogenic responses; the same are significantly co-expressed in 42% (P < 0.001)
column179:
hypothesizing that their action might promote ovarian cancer progression [40].

Even if many possible biomarkers are directly produced by tumoral cells
column180: recent evidences drew our attention on tumor microenvironment
column181: not only as an important factor in carcinogenesis
column182: but also as a source of new markers. In fact
column183: tumoral environment is constituted by a different cellular type system
column188: that actively attend to the tumoral progression process
column190:
measurable in biological fluids [41].

Matrix Metalloproteinase (MMP) are a group of calcium-zinc dependent photolytic enzymes
column191:
capable of reducing many extra cellular matrix component; they can be produced by tumoral and stromal cells [42].

In stromal cells
column194: a subgroup of no soluble enzymes
column196: are linked to a poor prognosis in patients with EOC. Although the role of MMPs as therapeutic targets remains to be further defined
column197: it is possible that broad MMP inhibitors (for example
column198:
Col-3; ref. [52]) targeting both epithelial and stromal MMPs may be useful in controlling ovarian cancer vascularization and metastasis [43].

EphA2 is a tyrosine-kinase receptor of 130Kda
column199: belonging to Eph family; EphA2 is over-expressed in many cancers
column201:
in which its expression is related to more aggressive cancer behaviour [44].

Interestingly
column202: the EphA2 gene is located on chromosome 1p36.1
column203: which is not only a genetic “<italic>hot spot</italic>” in cancer [<xref rid=""R45"" ref-type=""bibr"">45</xref>
column205:
but also the second most common site of complex karyotypic abnormalities in ovarian cancer [47].

Dohn et al. [48] showed that EphA2 transcription is regulated by p53
column206: a tumor suppressor protein is frequently mutated in ovarian cancer [<xref rid=""R49"" ref-type=""bibr"">49</xref>
column207:
50].

If further study will determine the role of p53 mutations in regulating EphA2 levels [49
column209:
EphA2 may be a therapeutic target to treat ovarian carcinoma patients who have p53 mutations [51].

In addition
column210: Hendrix <italic>et al.</italic> and Hess <italic>et al.</italic> have shown that EphA2 may play a role in vasculogenic mimicry [<xref rid=""R52"" ref-type=""bibr"">52</xref>
column212: targeting EphA2 may have direct anti-tumor and ant vascular effects. EphA2 role in tumorigenesis seems to concern invasion and angiogenesis process; in fact
column213: levels of this receptor in endothelial and tumoral cells are linked to a major density of micro vessels and to an high expression of MMP-9
column216: EphA2 represents an important predictor of clinical outcome and may be a potential ant vascular therapeutic target. Lin Y.G. <italic>et al.</italic> recently demonstrated that targeting EphA2 while concomitantly using conventional cytotoxic chemotherapy successfully decreased tumor growth <italic>in vivo</italic> at least in part by inducing tumor-associated endothelial cell apoptosis [<xref rid=""R55"" ref-type=""bibr"">55</xref>]
column217:
supporting EphA2 as a therapeutic antiangiogenic target.

PDEF belong to ETS transcription factor family
column218:
characterized by a conservative domain of 85 aa that bind DNA. They are nuclear factors that participate as effectors in Ras-MAPK pathway.

The mechanisms through which they seem to play a role in tumorigenesis or in ovarian cancer progression are still unknown; these factors could alter EOC physiology
column219: possibly in a way similar to that studied in mammalian cancer cell lines
column220:
where they significantly increase mobility and invasively.

Expression of this transcription factor has been studied
column221: at mRNA and proteic level: data obtained show that 70% of ovarian cancer over-expressed PDEF mRNA; on the other hand
column222:
only in 33% of higher stage disease over-expressed PDEF protein [56].

Different evidences suggest a link between inflammatory process and cancer onset [57].

Many molecules produced by inflammatory tumoral or associated cells
column224: play the role of mediator between these two processes. Cytokines are a heterogeneous protein family of low molecular weight
column227:
that can act as stimulators or inhibitors of growth and tumor progression [58].

Interleukin 13 (IL-13) is another cytokine with anti-inflammatory activity
column229: that plays an important role in many biological activities
column230: including cancer onset. IL-13 acts linking to its membrane receptor (IL-13R)
column232: IL13Ra1 and IL13Ra2. An altered expression of this cytokine has been observed in tumoral tissue
column233:
in respect to normal ovarian tissue [59].

High level of a2 chain has been revealed in 44 on 53 malign ovarian cancer samples (83%) [60].

Consistent with preclinical and clinical activities of IL13 cytotoxin in phase I/II clinical trials
column234:
Kioi et al. [60] showed that IL-13 cytotoxin mediates antitumor activity.

One of the characteristics of ovarian cancer is their intraperitoneal (IP) spread
column235: leading to an advanced stage of the disease invading other organs. Thus
column236: the IP route of administration of therapeutic agents seems to be an appropriate route for disseminated ovarian cancer therapy; therefore
column237: Kioi <italic>et al</italic>. investigated the efficacy of IL- 13 cytotoxin administrated IP using either a continuous infusion pump or bolus administration. By these routes of administration
column238: IL-13 cytotoxin mediated dramatic antitumor effects in very large established s.c. xenografted tumors [<xref rid=""R60"" ref-type=""bibr"">60</xref>] and therefore
column239:
IL-13 is a promising target for ovarian cancer therapy.

Higher levels of serum macrophage migration inhibitory factor (MIF) were found in ovarian cancer patients’ blood (sensibility of 77
column242: studies about co culture of macrophages with cancer cell lines showed that MIF expression is induced in a JNKII and NF-kB-dependent manner and acts inducing macrophages MMP release
column243:
promoting tumoral cells invasively [62].

MIF is an inflammatory cytokine that plays an important role in regulating innate and adaptive immune responses. The potent proinflammatory effect of MIF may mediate some of the stimulatory effects of inflammation on cancer progression; so
column244:
understanding its role on the inflammatory process associated with tumor development may provide insight into the mechanism by which chronic inflammation predisposes individuals to ovarian cancer and may open new venues for targeted therapy [63].

Attempts to provide insight into mechanisms of action of MIF have suggested that the protein acts by stimulating inflammatory signals in the ascitic microenvironment such as IL-6
column245:
IL-10 and TNF-α [62].

NGAL (Neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin) belongs to the lipocalin protein family. It is a protein stored in the specific granules of human neutrophils and works limiting bacterial growth at sites of infection. Lipocalins have unusual expression in tumoral tissues
column246:
respect to normal ones.

The NGAL concentration was higher in the serum of patients with borderline grade 1 tumors respect to grade 2 and grade 3 ones and to benign tumor. More studies are needed to further evaluate the role of NGAL in the progression of ovarian carcinoma and its potential targeting in diagnosis and treatment [64].

Tumoral cells capacity to escape to immunity surveillance was proposed as one of the cancer fundamental characteristic
column247: for the first time by Dann <italic>et al</italic>. [<xref rid=""R65"" ref-type=""bibr"">65</xref>]. One way used by cancer to escape from immunity system attach is the “immunosovvertion”
column250:
through superficial or soluble specific molecules actions.

CD46 is a membrane protein that protects cells against complement-mediated toxicity. An immunohistochemistry assay on 73 ovarian cancer biopsies showed that CD46 expression is linked to a poor prognosis [66].

RCAS1 (Receptor-binding cancer antigen expressed on SiSo cells) is a protein that induces immunity cells-RCAS1 receptor expressing apoptosis
column251:
like T cells and Natural Killer cells [67].

By immuno-localization studies
column252: an high RCAS1 expression was shown in breast
column253: gallbladder and colorectal cancers [<xref rid=""R68"" ref-type=""bibr"">68</xref>
column254: <xref rid=""R69"" ref-type=""bibr"">69</xref>]. Patients with uterine cancer showed higher serum levels
column256:
RCAS1 levels are correlated to therapy response [70].

ROLE OF THE PROTEOMICS IN THE IDENTIFICATION OF BIOMARKERS OF OVARIAN CANCER

Over the past decade
column257: the power of high-throughput technologies has stimulated their use in many bio-medical applications. In this field
column258: proteomics has become an important methodology in the biomarker identification. Using this method the expression of hundreds of proteins can be studied simultaneously
column259:
by taking advantage of their different biochemical properties.

This approach has been applied to ovarian cancer leading to the identification of several differentially expressed proteins related to platinum resistance. Among these
column263: GSTO1-1 and IDHc showed the more appreciable results
column264:
confirmed also by quantitative PCR and western blot [71].

Proteomics studies have also been applied to tumor classification by using diseased tissues and serum specimens: Bengtsson et al. used DIGE technology to distinguish between benign and malignant tumor groups leading to the identification of an heterogeneous groups of proteins involved in several cellular processes [72].

By coupling laser capture microdissection and 2-DE
column265: Brown Jones <italic>et al</italic>. revealed that the 52 KDa FK506 binding protein
column266:
RhoG-protein dissociation inhibitor and glyoxalase I were overexpressed in invasive ovarian cancer when compared to low malignant potential ovarian tumors [73].

The immune response to tumor associated antigens represents a possible serological tool for the diagnosis of cancer. Autoantibodies direct against tumor associated antigens presented by MHC I molecules have been identified by liquid chromatography - mass spectrometry/mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) using two human ovarian adenocarcinoma cell lines and serum sample from twenty patients
column267:
showing important implications in cancer detection and prognosis [74].

Recently
column268:
emerging technologies are unravelling the plasma proteome.

Surface-enhanced laser desorption and ionization with time-of-flight spectrometry (SELDI-TOF) was employed for the rapid identification of serum proteins in ovarian cancer patients.

The strength of SELDI technology is based on the selective binding of proteins on a solid-phase protein chip surface where the sample is ionized by an energy laser impulse.

The protein profile of each specimen is then analyzed by software to discovery changes in the protein pattern. Petricoin et al. analyzed the serum of unaffected controls and patients with ovarian cancers and were able to discriminate with a sensibility of 100% and a specificity of 94% all ovarian cancers in the early stage [75].

Among the possible marker identified with SELDI there was the Haptoglobin
column269:
a glycoprotein secreted by liver cells and implicated in the metabolism of hemoglobulin. High levels of Hp-α subunit were found serum of patients with ovarian cancer. The results of the ELISA test showed for Hp-α a 64% sensitivity and 90% specificity alone and 91% sensitivity and 95% specificity if combined with CA125.

Expression levels of 169 proteins were studied by Mor et al. by antibody microarray in serum of 28 healthy women
column270:
18 women newly diagnosed with EOC and 40 women with recurrent disease.

This analysis led to the identification of four proteins: leptin
column273: and insulin-like growth factor-II. Additional validation studies showed that the combination of the four proteins exhibited a sensitivity of 95%
column275:
a specificity of 95% and negative predictive value of 94% [76].

PROTEIN MARKERS IN BOT

An extensive analysis of the ovarian cellular pathways provided better insights in the molecular distinction between ovarian surface epithelium (OSE)
column276:
BOTs and high grade tumors.

A key feature is the modification in E-cadherin and N-cadherin levels
column277:
integral membrane glycoproteins that mediate calcium-dependent cell adhesions: a role for E-cadherin in the early events leading to cellular transformation has been proposed for two principal reasons.

The protein is expressed in inclusion cysts
column279:
borderline and malignant tumors of all stages but not in normal ovarian surface epithelium (OSE) [77].

Moreover
column280:
N-cadherin expression was detected in most benign and borderline tumors but was absent or heterogeneous in most carcinomas [78].

E-cadherin induces the activation of Akt and MAPK pathways and in this way increases proliferation and survival of ovarian cancer cells [79].

To corroborate these hypotheses
column281:
the expression of exogenous E-cadherin in mesenchymal IOSE-29 (immortalized-OSE) has been associated with the development of ovarian cancer [80].

The role of E-cadherin in advanced tumor and metastasis is still debated and not strictly related to the aim of this review. In general
column282:
the absence or the lower E-cadherin expression in ovarian cancers predicts poor patient survival when compared with ovarian tumors that express E-cadherin and correlates with high tumor grade and low overall survival rate [81].

Transforming growth factor-β (TGF- β) and epidermal growth factor (EGF) are known to promote EMT in ovarian cancer [82
column283:
83]. Smad3 is required to sustain TGF-β induced EMT. Analysis of Smad3 expression in microarrays of serous cystadenocarcinoma displayed lower levels of Smad3 nuclear expression than benign and borderline tumors and a correlation with N-cadherin expression and poor survival [84].

Activin A (βA)
column284: a member of the TGF- β family
column285: was found to regulate the activation status of Akt and GSK. In ovarian cancer
column286: βA expression was elevated in stromal cells from carcinomas. Moreover
column287: a different GSK-β phosphorylation status was identified in benign cystadenomas
column289:
and carcinomas [85].

EMT can be induced by EGF through the activation of JAK2/STAT3 signaling pathway as demonstrated by Colomiere et al. [86
column291: both phosphorylated JAK2 and activated STAT3 showed higher expression in high grade tumors respect to normal ovaries and borderline tumors [<xref rid=""R86"" ref-type=""bibr"">86</xref>]. The two cancer cell lines OVCA 433 and SKOV3 treated with EGF down-regulated the expression of epithelial-restricted E-cadherin and increased the expression of vimentin and α2
column292: α6 β1 integrin subunits [<xref rid=""R87"" ref-type=""bibr"">87</xref>]. EGF decreased also the expression of Neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin (NGAL) in the transition to mesenchymal like cells. <italic>In vivo</italic>
column293:
NGAL was not expressed in normal tissues while both BOT and grade I tumors showed an increased staining compared to grade 2 and 3 tumors [83].

Key cellular processes including adhesion and migration depend also largely on remodelling of cytoskeleton
column294:
a complex network of molecules whose organization influences not only cellular shape but also the interaction between cells and the ECM microenvironment.

Both actins and microtubules have a role in these processes; however
column295:
ovarian cancer cell invasion and migration seemed to be principally affected targeting actin dynamics [88].

Actin is one of the most abundant intracellular proteins; it is represented by three distinct isoforms
column297: β and γ. β and γ actin isoforms are expressed principally in non-muscle cells
column298:
α isoform in muscle cells. The organization of actin is driven by a plethora of proteins also known as Actin Binding Proteins under the control of specific signaling pathways [89].

Disorganisation of actin cytoskeleton contributes to alterations in growth control and tumorigenesis [90].

Furthermore
column299:
actin remodelling is involved in lamellipodia and pseudopodium formation during cancer cells invasion and metastasis [91].

The actin-binding protein Gelsolin regulates actin filaments length and severing. It is downregulated in a large variety of human cancers including BOT and ovarian carcinomas [92]. Gelsolin showed suppressive activity in ovarian cancer cells growth and was correlated with tumor grade [93].

Fascin is implied in the organization of F-actin in parallel bundles (actin-structures with a role in cell architecture) and dynamic structures including filopodia and lamellipodia [94]. Fascin was not expressed in normal epithelial ovarian tissue [95]
column302:
suggesting that fascin may play an important role in tumor progression [96].

In addition
column303: its stromal expression was significantly higher in malign epithelial ovarian tumors and BOT
column304:
compared to normal ovaries and benign epithelial ovarian tumors [97].

Also other cytoskeletal components
column306: have been reported to be involved in ovarian cancer. By two dimensional electrophoresis (2-DE) and mass spectrometry analysis
column307: Bengtsson <italic>et al.</italic> identified several IFs differentially expressed in benign and malignant tumors when compared to BOTs. The proteins identified were Vimentin
column308:
Keratin I cytoskeletal 19 and Lamin A/C respectively [98].

FUTURE PERSPECTIVES IN OVARIAN CANCER AND BOT DIAGNOSIS

High-throughput technologies have the potential to address this task and in particular
column309:
recent advances in mass spectrometry imaging may stimulate new research in this area.

The direct analysis of ovarian cancer tissue sections by matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization (MALDI) Imaging led to the identification of an 11S proteasome fragment as an ovarian cancer marker with a different cellular localization in benign and malign tissues [99].

So
column310: MALDI-Imaging could bypass the limitations of many current technologies allowing the visualization of proteins
column312: lipids and small molecules directly on thin sections cut from fresh frozen or paraffin embedded tissues (FFPE) [<xref rid=""R100"" ref-type=""bibr"">100</xref>
column313:
101] without long and tedious steps of separation and extraction.

In our laboratory we are also exploring the possibility to probe mechanical properties of cancer cells by an atomic force microscopy (AFM) in order to obtain a nanomechanical classification of BOTs. AFM is a versatile tool for imaging and measuring the elastic properties of living and fixed cells [102].

The great advantage of AFM lies in the unique possibility to work with living cells in physiological conditions at 37°C. Basically
column314: cells seeded into Petri dishes are scanned by a tip
column315:
which is mounted to a cantilever spring to obtain a topographic image of the sample at high spatial resolution.

CONCLUSION

Because of a lack of specific symptoms in the early phase and the limitations of existing markers for diagnostic methods
column318: one of the leading cause of death worldwide. The complete understanding of mechanisms controlling ovarian progression represents an important step toward the development of a future appropriate therapy based on genomic and proteomics findings. Nevertheless
column319: the study of low-abundant proteins and the need to analyze a large body of sample to extrapolate significant results
column320: make the proteomics approach labour-intensive and the potential of a gene therapy for ovarian cancer
column321: that involves blocking expression of specific ovarian oncogenes
column322: seems to be far to be applied. Currently
column323:
many genomic tests used to diagnose ovarian cancer or guide its therapy do not decrease women's risk of dying from this disease or do not improve their quality of life (QoL).

Therefore
column324: for their rapid investigations of biological specimens
column325: mass spectrometry and protein arrays are evolving as alternative methodologies to the “<italic>classic proteomics approach</italic>” facilitating their use at many points of the disease management and the expanding our knowledge on biomarkers is likely to lead to more individualization of therapy and improvements in ovarian cancer prognosis. Several works has been published on observing the impact of this technology in biomedical research [<xref rid=""R103"" ref-type=""bibr"">103</xref>]. We believe that the translation of all these information into the clinical practice could guide the development of appropriate targeted clinical therapy
column326:
overtaking the current invasive surgical approach and avoiding the uncertainty of a long term clinical and instrumental follow up of a possible recurrence.

This article [1] has been retracted by the authors due to extensive overlap with their own previous publication [2] and a number of other sources. In addition
column15:
there is duplication of some of the authors previously published results. The authors apologise to all concerned.

The Publisher and Editor regretfully retract this article [1] because the peer-review process was inappropriately influenced and compromised. As a result
column14: the scientific integrity of the article cannot be guaranteed. A systematic and detailed investigation suggests that a third party was involved in supplying fabricated details of potential peer reviewers for a large number of manuscripts submitted to different journals. In accordance with recommendations from <ext-link ext-link-type=""uri"" xlink:href=""http://publicationethics.org/news/cope-statement-inappropriate-manipulation-peer-review-processes#_blank"">COPE</ext-link> we have retracted all affected published articles
column15:
including this one. It was not possible to determine beyond doubt that the authors of this particular article were aware of any third party attempts to manipulate peer review of their manuscript.

Update posted {2<sup>nd</sup> July
column16:
2015}

BioMed Central has been informed of the outcome of a thorough investigation by the institution. That investigation found that the authors of this article [1] intended to purchase language editing services for their manuscript only and did not participate in influencing the peer review process. The institution has taken further steps to educate their researchers regarding best practice in research and publication ethics.

The online version of the original article can be found under doi:10.1186/1746-1596-9-133.

ReferenceShi J
column21: Gao W. Clinical application of contrast enhanced ultrasound to diagnose benign prostatic hyperplasia. Diagn Pathol. 2013;9:133.</mixed-citation></ref></ref-list></back>"	"""article-type=.retraction"""

The above article
column12: published online on 15 October 2015 in Wiley Online Library (<ext-link ext-link-type=""uri"" xlink:href=""http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ece3.1786/abstract"">http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ece3.1786/abstract</ext-link>)
column13: has been retracted by agreement between the authors
column16:
and John Wiley & Sons Ltd. The authors have requested the retraction of their paper because they mistakenly analyzed the wrong backcross lines. This mistake was only recently discovered and they are now in the process of repeating the experiment using the correct Backcross Introgression Lines. The authors apologize for this mistake.

Reference

Nie
column23:
et al. 2015. Screening of candidate genes and fine mapping of drought tolerance quantitative trait loci on chromosome 4 in rice (Oryza sativa L.) under drought stress. Ecology and Evolution 5(21):5007–5015. doi: 10.1002/ece3.1786.

column12:
may contain photographs or illustrations copyrighted by other commercial organizations or individuals that may not be used without obtaining prior approval from the holder of the copyright. Hyaluronan Activation of the Nlrp3 Inflammasome Contributes to the Development of Airway Hyperresponsiveness

Feifei Feng
column18:
and John W. Hollingsworth

Environ Health Perspect: http://dx.doi.org/10.1289/ehp.1205188RET

Online: 1 July 2015

Retraction of: Environ Health Perspect 120:1692–1698; doi:10.1289/ehp.1205188

The authors request retraction of “Hyaluronan Activation of the Nlrp3 Inflammasome Contributes to the Development of Airway Hyperresponsiveness.” Due to concerns about the initial data from the animal physiology laboratory at Duke
column19: the authors re-exported source data from the Flexivent machine and compared these data with raw data originally received from the animal pulmonary physiology laboratory. Results from these initial comparisons suggested potential inconsistencies in the data. Therefore
column20: the authors proceeded to replicate experiments of animal airway physiology presented in Figure 2A. These replicate experiments failed to validate the originally reported role of Nlrp3
column22: and caspase 1 in airway hyperresponsiveness after exposure to ozone. These observed inconsistencies significantly impact the overall conclusions of the manuscript. Therefore
column23:
all of the authors have agreed to retract this paper in an effort to correct the scientific record. The authors sincerely apologize for any inconvenience to the scientific community.

" """article-type=.retraction"""

G-Protein–Coupled Receptor 30 and Estrogen Receptor-α Are Involved in the Proliferative Effects Induced by Atrazine in Ovarian Cancer Cells

Retraction of: Environ Health Perspect 116:1648–1655; doi:10.1289/ehp.11297

The authors discovered that inadvertent errors occurred in sorting the files related to the presentation of the Western blots in Figures 6 and 8 and requested that their paper be retracted. The authors stand by the soundness of the study and have advised the Editor-in-Chief of their intention to submit an amended manuscript
column6:
for consideration for publication in a future issue of the journal. The authors apologize for any inconvenience caused.

column2: “Reproduced with permission from Environmental Health Perspectives”); pertinent reference information should be provided for the article from which the material was reproduced. Articles from EHP
column4:
may contain photographs or illustrations copyrighted by other commercial organizations or individuals that may not be used without obtaining prior approval from the holder of the copyright.The Role of the Extracellular Matrix Protein Mindin in Airway Response to Environmental Airways Injury

Environ Health Perspect 119(10):1403–1408 (2011)
column5:
doi: 10.1289/ehp.1003339

This article is being retracted at the request of the authors because of concerns about the accuracy of the initial data from the animal physiology laboratory at Duke University. The authors re-exported source data from the animal ventilator (FlexiVent) and compared the output with the raw data originally received from the animal pulmonary physiology laboratory. The results from these initial comparisons suggested potential inconsistencies in the data
column6:
so the authors requested that an independent laboratory replicate the experiments of animal airway physiology presented in Figure 1 and Figure 4. The results of the replicated experiments validated the originally reported central role of mindin in airway hyper-responsiveness after exposure to either lipopolysaccharide (LPS) or ozone.

Because the animal physiology laboratory at Duke University also analyzed cytokines
column7: the authors had an independent laboratory replicate experiments to analyze the original role of cytokines reported in Figure 3 and Figure 6. In these replicate studies
column8: which were limited in the number of animals and samples tested
column9:
the authors did not observe the same results and could not definitively determine whether or not the findings were valid.

The inconsistent results led the authors to take a conservative approach
column10:
and they agreed to retract this paper. They regret any inconvenience to the scientific community.

" """article-type=.retraction"""

Sustained Exposure to the Widely Used Herbicide Atrazine: Altered Function and Loss of Neurons in Brain Monoamine Systems

Retraction of: Environ Health Perspect 113:708-715 (2005); doi:10.1289/ehp.7783

The Office of Research Integrity has determined that Mona Thiruchelvam falsified and fabricated cell count data presented in “Sustained Exposure to the Widely Used Herbicide Atrazine: Altered Function and Loss of Neurons in Brain Monoamine Systems” [Rodriguez VM
column6:
Cory-Slechta DA. Environ Health Perspect 113:708-715 (2005)]. The Editor-in-Chief has retracted the paper.

For additional information

The Publisher and Editor regretfully retract this article [1] because the peer-review process was inappropriately influenced and compromised. As a result
column11: the scientific integrity of the article cannot be guaranteed. A systematic and detailed investigation suggests that a third party was involved in supplying fabricated details of potential peer reviewers for a large number of manuscripts submitted to different journals. In accordance with recommendations from <ext-link ext-link-type=""uri"" xlink:href=""http://publicationethics.org/news/cope-statement-inappropriate-manipulation-peer-review-processes#_blank"">COPE</ext-link> we have retracted all affected published articles
column12:
including this one. It was not possible to determine beyond doubt that the authors of this particular article were aware of any third party attempts to manipulate peer review of their manuscript.

The online version of the original article can be found under doi:10.1186/2047-783X-18-53.

column5:
provided the original work is properly cited.

At the request of the authors
column6: the article titled “Expression Profiling of Transcriptome and Its Associated Disease Risk in Yang Deficiency Constitution of Healthy Subjects” [<xref rid=""B1"" ref-type=""bibr"">1</xref>] has been retracted. The data were found to be unreliable and need to be reanalyzed
column7: and the results cannot support the conclusions. According to the new standards for diagnosing constitutions in Traditional Chinese Medicine
column8: samples B16 and B21 cannot be included in the Yang deficiency constitution. B16 also belongs to the Qi stagnation constitution and B21 also belongs to the phlegm dampness constitution. The discussion stated that “Yang deficiency constitution often led to occurrence of immune diseases
column9: such as enteritis due to immune problems
column13:
” but the work did not test causation and studied gene expression differences that have been previously associated with those conditions rather than directly studying the conditions. The conclusion that the study “proves [the] existence of Yang deficiency constitution” cannot be supported because the study did not validate this.

YuR.YangY.HanY.Expression profiling of transcriptome and its associated disease risk in yang deficiency constitution of healthy subjectsEvidence-Based Complementary and Alternative Medicine201620169149309810.1155/2016/1493098" """article-type=.retraction"""

Evidence-Based Complementary and Alternative Medicine has retracted the article titled “The Antioxidant and Starch Hydrolase Inhibitory Activity of Ten Spices in an In Vitro Model of Digestion: Bioaccessibility of Anthocyanins and Carotenoids” [1]
column6: as the High Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC) results were questioned and it was found that the underlying data for this study are not available
column7:
and thus the results of the article are questionable.

The following article: doi: 10.3390/foods2010064
column28: available online at: <uri xlink:type=""simple"" xlink:href=""http://www.mdpi.com/2304-8158/2/1/64"">http://www.mdpi.com/2304-8158/2/1/64</uri> [<xref rid=""B1-foods-02-00350"" ref-type=""bibr"">1</xref>]
column29: has been retracted by the authors because of some major errors in the broad field of identifying pesticide residue and its concentration. During random cross-check
column30: retention time of pesticides by HPLC did not match with the standard values. As a result
column31: the concentrations of all detected pesticides
column33: and health risk assessments were altered. These errors render the article [<xref rid=""B1-foods-02-00350"" ref-type=""bibr"">1</xref>] incorrect. All authors have confirmed that the reported results were produced using quite inappropriate procedures. As first author
column34: I take full responsibility for the retraction and any other errors in its contents
column35:
and would like to offer my apologies on behalf of my co-authors to the readership of Foods for any inconvenience caused by this retraction.

column17:
H. (2014). Front. Plant Sci. 5:421. doi: 10.3389/fpls.2014.00421mechanosensitive channelArabidopsisrootskewingwavingcalciumtouch responsemechanical stress

The authors and the journal wish to retract the 21 Aug 2014 article cited above in light of new experimental evidence.

Following the publication of the study
column18: we performed a DNA microarray analysis to detect genes with expression levels that were specifically lower in the <italic>mca2</italic>-null mutant than in the Col-0 wild type
column19: and found that the expression level of the <italic>AXR4</italic> gene (At1G54990)
column20: which encodes a protein required for the subcellular localization of the auxin influx carrier AUX1 (Dharmasiri et al.
column22: was significantly lower in the <italic>mca2</italic>-null mutant. To confirm this finding
column23: we then performed a semi-quantitative reverse transcription-PCR analysis using the primers axr4-f1 and axr4-Cr1 (Figure <xref ref-type=""fig"" rid=""F1"">1A</xref>)
column24: and found that the RT-PCR product was detectable in some <italic>mca2</italic>-null seedlings at wild-type levels but not in other <italic>mca2</italic>-null seedlings at all. This result suggested that some <italic>mca2</italic>-null seedlings have a certain lesion in the <italic>AXR4</italic> locus
column25: and a PCR-based genomic deletion analysis (Figures <xref ref-type=""fig"" rid=""F1"">1B
column26: C</xref>) followed by DNA sequencing confirmed this speculation. Our conclusion is that most of the <italic>mca2</italic>-null seedlings used in the study presented in the above paper had a homozygous 2592-bp deletion that started from the intron between exons 1 and 2 of the <italic>AXR4</italic> gene and reached the intron between exons 1 and 2 of the adjacent gene <italic>AT1G55000</italic> (Figure <xref ref-type=""fig"" rid=""F1"">1A</xref>). Therefore
column27: the phenotypes presented in the above paper may be ascribable to the <italic>axr4</italic> mutation
column29: or both or even triple mutations
column30:
but not to the mca2-null mutation. The AT1G55000 gene encodes the peptidoglycan-binding LysM domain-containing protein involved in a macromolecule catabolic process in the cell wall1.

Schematic representation of the AXR4 locus and PCR data to check its integrity. (A) The AXR4 locus and its adjacent locus At1g55000 in Arabidopsis thaliana (ecotype Col-0). The upper line drawing shows intact loci
column31: while the lower one shows loci with the 2592-bp deletion found in some <italic>mca2</italic>-null mutants. The position and orientation of the primers (axr4-f1
column34: and axr4-r9) are presented by arrows. Nucleotide numbering starts from the 5′-end of exon 1 in the <italic>AXR4</italic> gene. <bold>(B)</bold> An example of PCR data with the primers axr4-f1 and axr4-Gr1. <bold>(C)</bold> An example of PCR data with the primers arx4-f1 and axr4-r9. Genomic DNA was isolated from an <italic>mca2</italic>-null mutant with the <italic>mca2</italic><sup>−</sup>/<italic>mca2</italic><sup>−</sup>
